DOC.brief_summary: Adequate quality of bowel preparation(BP) is important for colonoscopy. Several guidelines recommend that split-dose of 4L PEG should be used as a standard regime for BP. However, the high-volume PEG still results in lower compliance to the regime and increased cost. Some high risk factors for inadequate BP have been identified, including old age, constipation, diabetes, the use of narcotics and prior history of inadequate BP. For average-risk patients without the high risk factors, the procedure of BP could be easier. In the previous study, with the use of single dose of 2L PEG, more than 90% of average-risk patients achieved adequate BP. Here investigators hypothesized that compared with the standard split dose of 4L PEG, single dose of 2L PEG may be not inferior in BP quality while may be accompanied with better tolerability.
DOC.brief_title: Effect of Single Dose of 2L PEG on Bowel Preparation in Average-risk Patients Undergoing Colonoscopy
DOC.criteria: Patients undergoing colonoscopy; Patients with average risks for inadequate BP (Patients were identified averagerisk if they did not meet any factor of the following risk factors): Constipation Diabetes Parkinson's disease History of stroke or spine cord injure History of abdominal or pelvic surgery Prior history of inadequate bowel preparation BMI>25 Use of tricyclic antidepressant or narcotics History of colorectal resection; Suspected colonic stricture or perforation; Incomplete or complete bowel obstruction; Use of prokinetic agents or purgatives within 7 days; Toxic colitis or megacolon; Pregnancy or lactation; Unable to give informed consent; Haemodynamically unstable.
